description:
Bartonella jaculi is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Bartonella. It is a fastidious, Gram-negative, facultative intracellular bacterium that is primarily associated with small rodents, particularly jerboas (Jaculus spp.), which are a type of jumping mouse found in North Africa and Central Asia.

Bartonella jaculi is known to infect the erythrocytes (red blood cells) of its rodent hosts, and it can be transmitted between individuals through the bites of ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice. The bacterium has a complex life cycle, involving both the vertebrate host and the invertebrate vector, and it is capable of causing asymptomatic, chronic infections in its rodent hosts.

While the precise pathogenic mechanisms and potential impacts on human health are not yet fully understood, some research suggests that Bartonella jaculi may be capable of infecting humans and potentially causing disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Further studies are needed to elucidate the epidemiology, clinical manifestations, and public health significance of this bacterial species.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Bartonella jaculi
